sentences.sentence: By Tracee SmithIndigenous housing(https://financialpost.com/tag/housing-market/) is not adequately funded and won't be unless we change the funding system.

The Assembly of First Nations estimates that $40 billion(https://www.afn.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/12/1.-Funding-First-Nations-Housing-Presentation-EN.pdf) is needed to raise Indigenous housing to a standard most Canadians would consider livable.
Just livable.

The 2023 federal budget(https://www.budget.canada.ca/2023/report-rapport/chap4-en.html) earmarked $4 billion over seven years for all First Nations housing across urban, rural, and northern communities, including Inuit and Metis peoples.
That's a difference of $36 billion.This gap between the housing Indigenous communities have and what they need is not new.
We keep going down the same socialized-housing path and netting the same dismal results.
Indigenous communities beat down the same government funding doors year after year, budget after budget.

And despite holding rights entrenched in treaties and legislation, many of our communities get the door slammed in their face.There is a better way, one that has been tested and proven and is used daily across Canada: private capital - which is essentially what it sounds like: money raised from assets not traded or available on public capital markets.

Though it's still often categorized as an "alternative investment," its role in Canadian investing has increased rapidly in recent years.So why haven't we been faster in using such funding to build more Indigenous homes?

Canadian financial institutions do welcome Indigenous deposits, but their loan-to-deposit ratios are lower in Indigenous communities than in other Canadian communities for investments like building housing, starting businesses, or increasing equity.
Financial institutions say the Indian Act prevents them from structuring guaranteed loans since they are unable to repatriate assets that sit on Crown land, such as property, should a default occur.
Or they say they require ministerial loan guarantees.Some bands have therefore been forced to develop their own financing solutions.

The Mississaugas of the Credit First Nation in Ontario, for instance, have established a revolving loan system in which members of the community can apply to borrow from a fund created out of band finances.
Rather than providing grants, the band offers loans that members can access, within set parameters, to support housing.But not all communities have the finances to do this.

The 400-500 Indigenous communities that do not have significant assets, lucrative land settlements, well-funded trusts or economic development corporations are essentially unable to access any capital.
It is to banks' and their investors' financial detriment that these conditions exist and the biases leading to them persist.

Considerable unrealized equity sits within both the private sector and Indigenous communities that is ready to be invested in building livable housing.Private capital is able to circumvent these actual and, in some cases, mainly perceived challenges.
Indigenous communities and would-be private investors set their own terms and conditions together.
The level of investment can meet specific community needs.

If six homes are needed, the Indigenous community is limited only by its investment capacity, not by an arbitrary housing allocation, inflexible policy guideline, or (sometimes) lending practices that are outright discriminatory.Where the banks are compartmentalized and can only lend to home-buyers within "Guideline B-20 for Residential Mortgage Underwriting," private lenders can be more creative.
Private creditors can draw from aspects of commercial, corporate, and real estate lending when working with Indigenous communities.
They generally have more room to be flexible and nimble.

Understanding community issues and having on-the-ground relationships with communities and a vision of potential impacts is where a private fund can be more innovative and ultimately more successful than its big-bank counterparts.Stop China's neo-Marxist EV trade war(https://financialpost.com/opinion/stop-china-neo-marxist-ev-trade-war)Ottawa's EV timeline is way too optimistic(https://financialpost.com/opinion/ottawa-ev-timeline-way-too-optimistic)Cutting university budgets always messy, political(https://financialpost.com/opinion/cutting-university-budgets-messy-political)There has really been only one door for Indigenous people to knock on for housing dollars, and that's been the federal government.

It's high time we tapped private resources to participate in the solution, providing not only much-needed housing for Indigenous communities but giving investors the opportunity to earn a return while doing something good.Tracee Smith, a member of Missanabie Cree First Nation in Ontario, is president and CEO, Keeywaywin Capital Inc., an Indigenous-owned private credit fund.Bookmark our website and support our journalism: Don't miss the business news you need to know - add financialpost.com(https://financialpost.com/ ) to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here(https://financialpost.com/newsletters/ ).
